text: FWIW, I started a blog about 10 years ago to support my freelance software development and consulting (knowing nothing really about content marketing, and just viewing it as a "follow me if you think this is interesting" journal).  I never really promoted it and, I might even say, I conspicuously avoided promoting it -- the most I ever really did was "hey I wrote a blog post" on social media.

text: Over the last decade, I built an audience that peaked at thousands of followers and, if memory serves, something like 500K page views per year (much less now, because the content is more specialized and much less frequent).

text:
I mention this arc not to flex in any way or even offer it as a piece of advice, but rather to illustrate a few points:
• Just showing up and giving readers what they seemed to want, on a long time line, was its own form of promotion.
• It seemed, in retrospect, less important to self promote than to arm readers with ways to me-promote if they liked the content (e.g. buttons to share on Reddit or whatever)
• It could be purely anecdotal or a form of survivorship bias, but I always felt like going really light on self-promotion made it a higher-reward, longer-game, in terms of audience engagement.

text:
That said, I had no commercial interest in this hobby for a long time, so time was on my side.  FWIW if I do have to self promote (or worse, do cold outreach or something), here are a few things that help me -- an intensely spotlight avoiding introvert -- power through the awkwardness:
1. Systemize/SOP the promotion so that it's a rote task -- fewer decisions means less agonizing.
2. Identify places where your content really and immediately would offer value to the audience.
3. Separate drafting the promotion copy from sending it, and make those two separate todos on your list.  I always found the words tumbled out more easily if I was telling myself in the back of my mind "I can always just decide not to send this, later, or change the phrasing or whatever."  (I'd rarely do that, but drafting took way less time if I felt I had the option)
